conversation.content: [atónito] Eh, perdona, no puedes estar aquí durante la, [sin aliento], prueba de sonido, o sea, esta azotea está restringida para el equipo del concierto y, bueno, espera—¿de verdad eres tú?

[tembloroso] Mamá, han, em, han pasado 17 años desde que, [voz quebrada], saliste por esa puerta, y o sea, ¿ahora estás colgada del lateral de este edificio como, pues, como si no hubiera pasado nada?

Eh, tengo tres edificios más que revisar hoy pero, bueno, [vacilante], podría volver sobre las 9 si de verdad quieres, o sea, intentar entendernos. [voz temblorosa]

[firme] No vuelvas a desaparecer porque, eh, no te daré otra oportunidad después de esta, y quiero decir, [vulnerable], necesito saber si de verdad eres capaz de quedarte esta vez o si, pues, debería dejarte ir para siempre. [pausa]

original_conversation.content: [stunned] Um, excuse me, you can't be up here during the, [breathless], soundcheck, I mean, this rooftop is restricted for the concert crew and, well, wait—is that really you?
[caught off-guard] Well, um, I'm just here to fix the phone lines that, [nervous], got damaged in last night's storm, so, uh, I didn't know there was an event happening up here today.

[trembling] Dad, it's, um, it's been seventeen years since you, [voice cracking], walked out that door, and I mean, now you're just hanging off the side of this building like, well, like nothing happened?
I didn't know you'd, um, be here working this event, I mean, [shocked], I heard you were doing sound engineering but, well, never imagined we'd cross paths like this. [long pause]
You heard about my career but never thought to, [bitter], reach out or congratulate me on making something of myself? [laughs sadly]

[desperate] Every concert I mix, every band I work with, I keep, [searching], hoping maybe one day you'd show up in the audience because Mom said you, [nostalgic], loved music more than anything except, [voice breaking], apparently more than us.

[angry] Not fair is growing up wondering what I did, [hurt], wrong to make my father disappear, spending years in therapy trying to, [exhausted], understand why I wasn't enough to make you, [broken], stay.

[frustrated] So, um, you're still keeping secrets even now when I'm standing here as, [determined], an adult who deserves the truth about why my father abandoned me, and, well, you're acting like I should just, [sarcastic], accept your vague explanations and move on, I mean, like those seventeen years of silence didn't nearly destroy me?

[softer] This equipment I'm running generates about forty thousand watts of power, [technical], enough to blow out someone's hearing permanently if I make one mistake with the, [focused], monitors.
[confused] That's an interesting change of subject but I'm, [curious], listening to whatever you need to say right now. [clears throat]
Well, um, the point is that I learned to handle dangerous things with, [proud], precision because I never wanted to hurt anyone the way, uh, you hurt us when you left.
[emotional] God, you became everything.
The band starts their soundcheck in ten minutes and I need to, [professional], finish calibrating these speakers, but after the show tonight maybe we could, [hopeful], actually talk?
Um, I've got three more buildings to service today but, well, [tentative], I could come back around nine if you really want to, I mean, try to understand each other. [voice shaking]

[firm] Don't disappear again because, um, I won't give you another chance after this, and I mean, [vulnerable], I need to know if you're actually capable of staying this time or if, well, I should just let you go forever. [pause]

scenario: A monitor engineer working a rooftop concert discovers the telephone lineman suspended from safety gear outside the building is their estranged parent who left when they were young.
